question:
There exist constants $c_2,$ $c_1,$ and $c_0$ such that
\[x^3 + x^2 - 5 = (x - 3)^3 + c_2 (x - 3)^2 + c_1 (x - 3) + c_0.\]Find $c_2^2 + c_1^2 + c_0^2.$
agents_response:
Expanding the right side using the binomial theorem, we have
\[(x - 3)^3 + c_2 (x - 3)^2 + c_1 (x - 3) + c_0 = x^3 - 9x^2 + 27x - 27 + c_2 (x^2 - 6x + 9) + c_1 (x - 3) + c_0.\]Matching coefficients, we get
\begin{align*} x^3 - 9x^2 + 27x - 27 &= x^3 + x^2 - 5, \\ c_2(x^2 - 6x + 9) &= -9x^2, \\ c_1(x - 3) &= 27x, \\ c_0 &= -27. \end{align*}From the second equation, we have $c_2 = -9.$ From the third equation, we have $c_1 = -81.$ From the fourth equation, we have $c_0 = -27.$ Therefore, $c_2^2 + c_1^2 + c_0^2 = (-9)^2 + (-81)^2 + (-27)^2 = \boxed{7389}.$
